SummaryOfEvents: Alongside the quay, the ship was hit by M/V LAURA HELENA, Cyprus. The starboard part of the bridge was smashed and starboard bulkward was pressed down. A hole in the hull to the engine room flooded the room but the ship remained floating. The ship was later towed to Hull for repair.

On the 17/12/96 at 20:30, the MV KORALLE left Varberg (Sweeden) with destination to UK with a full of cargo of wood. 
At 22:00 the vessel suffered from heavy list of 45Â° to her starboard side. 
The Master tried to stabilize the vessel unsuccessfully.
At 22:40 three of the crewmembers abandonned the ship. The Master and the Chief Mate stayed on board.
A patrol boat was in stand by to give support to the vessel and started to tow her back into port at 23:00.
At about 232:30 the vessel came aground in position 57Â° 06,4N 012Â°13,4E. At the time the vessel was stuck.
On the 18th and 19th December 1996, the decks cargo were discharged and the vessel was towed back into port of Varberg on 20/12/96. Subsequently the vessel was completely discharged.

Shortly after 14:00 hours on 14 December 1996, the fully loaded Liberian bulk carrier Bright Field temporary lost propulsion power as the ship was navigating outbound in the lower Mississippi River at New Orleans, Louisiana. The vessel struck a wharf adjacent to a populated commercial area that included a shopping mall, a condominium parking garage, and a hotel. No fatality resulted from the accident; and no one aboard the Bright Field was injured; however; 4 serious injuries and 58 minor injuries were sustained during evacuation of shore facilities; a gaming ship, and an excursion ship located to the Bright Field and to shoreside facilities were estimated at about $20 million.

On the morning of Friday 13 December 1996, the Australian fishing ship Moonshot was trawling for prawns off Pakhoi Bank, north of Cape Upstart, Northern Queensland. At about 03:30 hours, with the ship trawling in a north-north-westerly direction, the Skipper handed over to a deckhand and went below to get some sleep. 
Shortly before 04:00 hours, the Skipper was aroused by a shout from the deckhand. Scrambling up into the wheelhouse, he saw the bow of a ship very close on the starboard bow and only had time to brace himself before the stem of Moonshot came in contact with the port bow of the ship. Moonshot was pushed around to port, heeling dangerously to port as the starboard fishing boom came in contact with the side of the ship. As the ship passed clear, the deckhand saw the word ISTANBUL on its stern. 
The ship did not stop, or respond to the Skipper's calls on VHF 16. 
Moonshot received damage to the stem and starboard bow, also to the starboard fishing boom. After ascertaining that the ship was not taking water, the crew retrieved the fishing gear, then returned to Townsville for Moonshot to undergo repairs. 
The Turkish bulk carrier Gumbet was on a ballast passage from Hong Kong to Geelong and had disembarked the Barrier Reef pilot off Cairns at 12:30 hours on Thursday 12 December 1996. 
When the Master went to the bridge at 06:30 hours on 13 December, for his customary morning check, he was informed that the Second Mate had experienced a close quarters situation with a fishing ship at 03:40 hours, off Tink Shoal. The Master telexed a brief account of the reported incident to the ship's owner. 
When Gumbet arrived at Geelong on 18 December, it bore signs of a recent contact between the light and load water lines on the port bow

On the afternoon of 06 December 1996, the Ypapadi arrived off the port off GaspÃ©, QuÃ©bec. Although pilotage is not compulsory in the port, the ship owner had instructed the agents in Montreal to provide the ship with a pilot upon arrival at the harbour entrance. The sub-agent in GaspÃ© was not successful in securing the services of an individual with previous pilotage experience, and a representative of the sub-agent boarded the Ypapadi to assist the master in his approach to the berth. A lack of communication between this person and the master led each to believe that the other had the conduct of the ship. In the approach to the berth at a position where a large course alteration was required, neither gave the appropriate order to the quartermaster, and the ship grounded on the north side of the harbour. The Ypapadi was refloated one week later. There was no damage to the ship and no pollution.

On 5 December 1996, the sail training ship Concordia, registered in the Commonwealth of the Bahamas, was on passage from Brisbane to Darwin in the Northern Territory. On deck, routine maintenance was being conducted by some of the students. 
Shortly before 11:45 hours on 5 December, one of the students, using a rotary grinder, was removing rust from the door of the battery locker, which was situated at deck level, in the after housing, below the wheelhouse. He paused and called over the Bosun's Mate who looked at the work before turning away and walking towards the forward housing. At that instance, the Bosun's Mate recalled being "moved" over a metre, putting her hands over her ears and hearing a noise. Another student, working on the port side about 5 metres from the bridge front, saw a dark shape, which he took to be a body, being thrown over the port rail. 
The Master, who was on watch and fixing the ship's position at the time, and most of the crew heard an explosion and went to the deck. Within a very few seconds life buoys were thrown overboard, one with a smoke marker. The Master could see the student in the water close to the smoke buoy, but as he watched the student disappeared from view. 
Within 3 minutes, a rescue boat was launched and was making for the smoke buoy and Concordia was turned about. No trace of the student could be found, except for a pair of shoes on the deck and some evidence of blood on the deck, on the ship's rail and near the ship's side. 
The maritime rescue authorities were alerted and Concordia, assisted by a helicopter and a fixed wing aircraft, searched the area that afternoon, into the evening until 19:15 hours. The following morning the search resumed at sunrise and Concordia was later joined by a single fixed wing aircraft. The search for the student was abandoned at about 12:30 hours, and after a short service Concordia resumed passage for Darwin.

SOLASStatus: ESTER J: Unknown/unspecified, PACIFIC PREMIER: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Ester J, a steel hulled fishing vessel, based in San Remo, Victoria, had been fishing for shark about 50 miles south of Port Phillip during the 25 November 1997, with a crew of three aboard.
At about 0100 Eastern Australian Standard Time on 26 November, the Skipper anchored the vessel in about 75 m of water in position 39Â° 7.88â South 145Â° 19.25â East, about 33 miles south of Phillip Island. The vessel switched on its anchor light and the Skipper and one of the deck hands went to bed, leaving one deck hand on watch.
At or a little after 0200, the deck hand noticed the lights of a ship approaching from an easterly direction. He realised that the vessel was bearing down towards Ester J and he immediately called the Skipper. The Skipper started the fishing vesselâs engine and called the unidentified vessel on channel 16 VHF, with no response. There was no time to weigh anchor or cut the cable, so he put the engine full astern, but the two vessels collided at about 0215.
The fishing vessel sustained damage to the port side. The large vessel did not stop or make any attempt to call Ester J. A quick inspection of the damage showed the vessel was not in immediate danger of sinking
Ester Jâs Skipper called Melbourne Maritime Communications Centre on the radio frequency 4125 kHz, reporting the incident. He then called his home by mobile telephone.
Nobody was injured and no pollution resulted from the collision.
The hull remained watertight and the engine was operational, so the Skipper set course for San Remo, where the vessel arrived safely at 0800 on 26 November.

Location: Below Lock NÂ°1, Port Weller, Ontario
SummaryOfEvents: The "Mallard" was inbound for Lock No. 1, Welland Canal and was landing at slow speed on the northernmost section of the tie-up wall. The vessel was still making headway when she came bodily alongside the wall. When the vessel's stern became subject to bank suction and was drawn towards the wall, the bow swung to port across the channel. A few minutes earlier, the "Canadian Enterprise" had departed Lock No. 1 outbound and was keeping to the east of the centre line of the channel. As the bow of the "Mallard" swung across the channel towards the "Canadian Enterprise", measures to avoid collision were taken by both vessels but the port bow of the "Mallard" struck the port side of the "Canadian Enterprise". No one was injured but both vessels were damaged. There was no pollution.

SOLASStatus: COLUMBUS VICTORIA: Unknown/unspecified, SAMPET HOPE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 23:00 hours on 16 November 1996, the German flag container ship Columbus Victoria anchored in Port Phillip Bay with Point Gellibrand bearing 353 x 1.75 miles. The ship anchored to the port anchor with 5 shackles on deck in about 12 m of water. The ship's draught was 6.3 m forward and 7.25 m aft. Sea watches were maintained on the bridge and the engine was put on 20 minutes notice. The ship was due to berth at about 06:00hours on 18 November 1996.
At 12:20 hours on 17 November, the chemical tanker Sampet Hope anchored with Point Gellibrand bearing 346 x 1.35 miles. The anchor position was about 4.5 cables north and east of Columbus Victoria. The tanker had a cargo of non-volatile (kerosene type) solvent in four centre tanks. The weather at this time was fair with a south-south-west to south-west wind at about 8 knots. Sea watches were maintained on the bridge and the engine was left on instant (3-4 minutes) readiness.
From about 14:00 hours on 17 November, the wind backed and increased in strength. At 18:00, the wind speed was recorded at the Harbour Control Centre as west of south at 17-25 knots. By 22:00, the wind was noted as southerly at 21-31 knots, gusting to 35 knots, with rain. The sea at the anchorage was described as "short and choppy".
At about 22:15 hours, the officer of the watch aboard "Columbus Victoria" detected the ship was dragging anchor, the Master was called and the engine room given notice that the engine was required.
At about 22:20 hours, the officer of the watch on Sampet Hope realised that Columbus Victoria was dragging anchor and that risk of collision existed. He called the Master and at 22:26 hours the engine was ordered. At about 22:30 hours, crew members of "Sampet Hope" were deploying fenders as the container ship approached. The engine and bow thrust were ready for use.
At a time put at between 22:32 and 22:33 hours, the two vessels collided. The initial impact was taken forward of the tanker's collision bulkhead, on the bulbous bow and the flare of the starboard bow. At about this time "Columbus Victoria" let go the other anchor, but it did not arrest the drift.
A second impact occurred at 22:36 hours. By using the bow thrust, engine and rudder, Sampet Hope cleared Columbus Victoria at 22:40 hours and the tanker weighed anchor at 22:52 hours and the master repositioned the ship.
At about 22:40 hours, the engine on Columbus Victoria was ready for manoeuvring. At 22:50 hours, the ship started to manoeuvre and weighed anchor at 23:05 hours, re-anchoring at 23:30 hours with 7 shackles in the water to the south of its original position.

Location: South East Coast of South Africa
SummaryOfEvents:
The MV Cordigliera, built in 1979 in UK, arrived in Durban on 1 November 1996 from Beira (Mozambique). She completed loading and securing the cargo at 03:50 hours on 13 November 1996 and sailed at 08:30 that day, bound for Cape town with 29 crew onboard.
The weather on sailing was reasonable but deteriorated during the day with a strong to (later)  gale force South Westerly wind and a high South Westerly Swell. 
The master spoke to his Agents in Durban at about 21:00 hours that evening and reported that he was progressing slowly into the South Westerly gale but that everything was fine. At 22:24 hours, the master contacted Durban Radio and reported that she was taking water rapidly in number 1 hold and that she required immediate assistance. He gave her position as 31Â° 21âS and 30Â° 01âE.
Radio contact was immediately therefore lost. 
The Coast Radio Station immediately transmitted a âMay-day-Relayâ message and a number of ships arrived on scene at about 00:45 hours on 14 November 1996. Some debris, oil, 2 empty liferafts and 2 empty lifeboats were spotted during the night, but no sign of any survivors. At first light a full scale air and sea Search and Rescue operation was launched. Five bodies were spotted, but because of the extreme weather and sea conditions these could not be recover by the helicopters or surface craft.
The lost of the ship cause a substantial oil slick and large areas of the shore of the Eastern Cape were contaminated.
The wreck of the ship was later located in position 31Â° 21.86 and 30Â° 01.85âE in a depth of 86 metres.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

ShipType1: Other Dry Cargo (livestock, barge, heavy cargo, etc.) Carrier

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
Early on 5 November 1996, the 140,086 tonnes deadweight Malaysian flag bulk carrier Giga 2 was nearing completion of discharge of a cargo of iron ore at No. 2 discharge berth, Port Kembla. Due to the ship's light condition, the unloader could not be positioned over No. 1 hold, to remove the 1080 tonnes of cargo remaining in that particular hold. At the suggestion of the shift supervisor, ballast was pumped into No. 4 hold, which was permissible under the ship's operations manual. Pumping of ballast into No. 4 hold commenced at 05:30 hours.
After the lunch break, two terminal workers descended into No. 5 hold, where the unloader was working, to clear iron ore from around the bottom of the forward spiral access ladder. The spiral ladder terminated at the top of the lower stool, six metres above the tank top. They had just completed this task and were about to climb the ladder when the bulkhead to the starboard side of the centre line, between No. 5 hold and the ballasted No. 4 hold, collapsed. Both workers were immediately engulfed by the deluge and, although one was able to haul himself clear, the other remained submerged.
The shift supervisor was working in his office ashore and, alerted by calls over the radio from the Hatchman, dashed on board and immediately descended the ladder into No. 5 hold. Up to his neck in the swirling water and guided by the Hatchman above, he was able to grab hold of the submerged worker. Assisted by another terminal worker, who had followed him into the hold, he was able to haul the unconscious and apparently lifeless worker clear of the water. The shift supervisor then administered cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR), which was successful in restoring breathing in the worker. Very shortly afterwards an ambulance officer arrived on the scene and administered oxygen, before the worker was lifted from the hold and taken to hospital.
To identify the circumstances which led to the collapse of the bulkhead, the ship's procedures and documentation were examined. Also a detailed examination of the bulkhead between holds 4 and 5 was undertaken, which included a metallurgical examination and finite element analyses of the failed bulkhead.

The vessel was enroute from Oxelosund (Sweeden) to Spain with a full cargo of wood.
On 29/10/1996 at 20:00, the vessel suffered from a total failure of he main engine gearbox while she was in the North Sea passing the Isle of Juist (GE).
The weather conditions were poor to bad, wind North West Bft 9 to 10.
On 29/10/1996, the crew of 5 abandonned the ship by helo.
On 30/10/1996, a crew of 4 returned to the vessel by helo and tried to establish a towing line between the tug and the vesssel.
On the 1/11/1996 the vessel was dragged from the ground and towed to the port of Emden.
No loss of life or injuries. The manning of the vessel was iaw the minimum safe manning requirements of the flag State.

On the morning of Saturday 19 October 1996, the Antigua and Barbuda flag cargo ship Karin B entered Corner Basin, Victoria, bound for Esso Australia Limited's private terminal at Barry Beach, where it was to discharge sections of a new drilling rig. Outside the bar, off Corner Inlet, the wind was very fresh from the north-west, but it eased to about 15 knots as the ship passed through the inlet. Although the sky was threatening and a frontal change forecast, those on the bridge considered they had time to berth the ship before the front arrived. 
While making the turn from Toora Channel into the dredged Barry Beach Channel, Karin B was caught by a sudden increase in wind and was blown on to the mud bank to the starboard side of the dredged channel. The ship listed 18Â° to port before stabilising and was towed off the bank during the next flooding tide by the supply ship Lady Valesia. 
No damage was sustained by the vessel and no pollution occurred.

Location: Wesfield Ferry Crossing, Saint John River, New Brunswick
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: On 15 October 1996, the cable used by the cable ferry F-39 parted when the ship was in mid-river on a regular run at the Westfield crossing between Baxter Pont and Hardings Point, New Brunswick. In the high winds and waves, which subsequently hampered rescue efforts, the drifting ferry was carried down river. After approximately two hours, a line was attached to the F-39 from a tug which had been dispatched to the scene, and the ferry was towed into the sheltered waters of McCormick Cove on Kennebecasis Island. No one was injured and there was no pollution or damage to the ship.

At approximately 11:05 hours (local time used throughout report) p, 27 September 1996, the 560 foot long product Tanker Julie N collided with the south bascule pier of the Portland-South Portland Bridge in Portland, Maine, USA. There were no injuries, however, the Julie N sustained a 33 foot long hole in its hull beneath the waterline and spill approximately 4,000 barrels of oil into the harbour.

M/V DONG JIN HOPE left Busan Korea at 18.00 on 10 September 1996 for Doku Ya Ma Japan with container 27EA and general cargo 17 tons. At 19.30, the boatswain and the sailer taken over duty then kept true course 126Â° speed 12.5its.
He found the vessel, NEPTUNE ALDEBARAN, with portbow 45Â° and distance 7 mile.
As the result of the failure of NEPTUNE ALDEBARAN to look out and to avoid the collision, the collision happened with DONG JIN HOPE bow and NEPTUNE ALDEBARRAN starboard side center. DONG JIN HOPE damaged her bow shell plate length 2M X height 1.5M and bulbous bow. 
The Japanese tug boat KOYO MARU towed her to the Busan Korea for repairing.

SOLASStatus: FRIO NARUTO: Unknown/unspecified, WEN HE: Unknown/unspecified

ShipType1: Other Dry Cargo (livestock, barge, heavy cargo, etc.) Carrier

SummaryOfEvents:
On the morning of 17 August 1996, the 25,093 gross tonne Hong Kong flag container ship Matilda Bay was crossing the Great Australian Bight, on passage from Melbourne to Fremantle in Western Australia. At 08:00 hours, the ship was in the position 37Â°22 S, 131Â°50 E, approximately 240 nautical miles WSW of Kangaroo Island. At about 08:00 hours, the Second Engineer reported to the bridge that sunlight could be seen coming into the forecastle through the small âboobyâ hatch on the forecastle head. 
The Chief Officer, after leaving the bridge, made his way forward along the main deck to investigate, taking the Bosun and two Able Seamen (ABs) with him. He had not advised the Third Mate, now on watch on the bridge, nor anybody else, that he was going to the forecastle. He had no radio with him. The four men went onto the forecastle where they found the lid of the booby hatch had been torn off. Attempts to replace it proved fruitless, as it was distorted, so the Chief Officer sent the Bosun to get materials with which to improvise a hatch cover. 
Shortly after this, a green sea swept the forecastle, carrying one AB right over the top of the windlass and the other AB against the front of it. The Chief Officer was swept underneath the windlass. The AB who had been swept over the windlass, stunned, called out to the other two who did not reply. He, thinking they had been washed overboard, made his way off the forecastle and told the Bosun what had happened. The Bosun sent the duty AB to the bridge to inform the Officer of the Watch of a man overboard situation. 
The Officer of the Watch commenced a Williamson turn and sounded the âman overboardâ alarm. Shortly before 09:00 hours, while the vessel had started searching for the men believed overboard, the other AB, recovering on the forecastle, found the Chief Officer under the windlass. Making his way aft he told the Bosun that the Chief Officer was still on the forecastle. The Chief Officer was stretchered aft to the shipâs hospital. He had suffered severe head and chest injuries and a broken leg. It was found later that the two ABs had not sustained serious injury. At 09:45 hours, the MRCC in Canberra was contacted asking for medical advice and for the nearest port for a medevac of all three. 
Those tending the Chief Officer were unable to stem the profuse bleeding from his head injuries. In spite of prolonged CPR and the administering of oxygen, all vital signs had disappeared by 13:30 hours and it was concluded that he had died at some time before that. The ship resumed its course to Fremantle where it arrived on the evening of 19 August 1996.

At approximately 16:00 hours on 8 August 1996, the Indonesian cargo ship Niaga 46, arrived at Christmas Island, about 4.5 miles to the Northwest of Flying Fish Cove. The ship was due to berth at 06:00 hours the following morning to load 7,600 tonnes of rock phosphate. 
Christmas Island is âsteep toâ and ships do not anchor but drift while waiting to berth. Niaga 46 hove to in position with North West Point bearing 270 x 2.5 miles, to drift overnight. Sea watches were maintained and the engine was on ten minutes notice of readiness. The wind was blowing from a southerly direction at 17 knots and the anticipated current was west going at about 2 knots. 
By 21:32 hours, the ship had drifted west towards North West Point and the Third Mate decided to reposition the ship. At 23:23 hours, Niaga 46 was repositioned about 2.5 miles due east of North West Point. 
At midnight, the Second Mate had not arrived on the bridge so the Third Mate handed over the watch to the 12-4 apprentice and left the bridge at about 00:05 hours. The Second Mate arrived on the bridge at about 00:10 hours and switched on the starboard radar to check the shipâs position. The radar showed Niaga 46 as being close to the land east of North West Point. He rang the duty engineer and requested use of the engine. The engine was ready at 00:39 hours, however, before the Second Mate could manoeuvre clear of the land the ship grounded at 00:47 hours about 6 cables east of North West Point. 
At 06:05 hours, contact was made with the Harbour Master, Christmas Island, and he boarded the ship a little after 07:00 hours on 9 August. The Harbour Master took charge of the refloating operation and, after a number of unsuccessful attempts, the vessel was refloated at 23:00 hours on 9 August. 
The ship suffered extensive damage and was taken in tow to a repair port in Indonesia

At 2329 on 3 August 1996, the SEA SPARKLE sailed from Inchon, Korea to Mokpo, Korea to discharge a cargo of logs. The voyage was uneventful until about 1134 on 4 August when the visibility was reduced because of mist and fog. The vessel began sounding the automatic fog signal, the bridge doors were opened and the navigation lights were lit. The steering was switched to manual and both radars were switched on and were operating properly. An ordinary seeman was also sent to the forecastle as a lookout.
At 1619, the visibility was further reduced and current in the area became confusing to interpret and thus the Master ordered half ahead and then slow ahead to keep headway. At approximately 1626, a contact was identified on the radar which was set at the 3-6 mile range. The contact was 30Â° on the starboard bow and was about 1.3 miles away. This was the first time the contact was noticed. The third Officer attempted to locate the vessel using the ARPA but the vessel was too small to be detected. Attempts were made, via radio, to contact the vessel in question; no answer was received. At approximately 1630 the lookout noticed a black shadow on the starboard bow and immadiately collided with the KOREX INCHON. 

The KOREX INCHON was capsized as a result of the collision and all 10 people onboard were rescued by the SEA SPARKLE. The SEA SPARKLE was surveyed for damages and was later allowed to off load its remaining cargo then proceed to Shanghai for repair.

M/V KUM KANG HO laden with sea sand left the offshore of Batam with 15 crewmembers and was en route to the Pasir Panjang Dumping area on a regular trip. M/V JOHAN II (unknow steel ship) was sailing to the Jong Fairway from West petroleum anchorage. 
The bow of M/V JOHAN II strucked the starboard bow of M/V KUM KANG HO.
ShipType1: Other Bulk Dry (cement, woodchips, urea and other specialized) Carrier

SummaryOfEvents: On Saturday 27 July 1996, approximately 3 hours  after leaving Juneau, Alaska, a fire broke out in the laundry room of the passenger ship Universe Explorer resulting in the deaths of 5 crew members from smoke inhalation. The fire was brought under control one hour and 15 minutes later and the ship returned to Auk bay anchorage under her own power.

On 22 July 1996, the STOLT HAWK was inbound on the Houston Ship channel when it encountered the tug LAURA HADEN in the vicinity of bouys 25 and 26. The vessels agreed to port a passage. Suddenly the LAURA HADEN turned directly into the path of the STOLT HAWK and at 0334 the vessels collided. Investigations would later reveal that the LAURA HADEN most probably suffered a steering casualty thus causing the rapid shift in course that placed her in front of the STOLT HAWK. The LAURA HADEN capsized and three of its crewmembers were killed and one was seriously injured. There was no reported of oil spill as a result of the collision.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: Piper Reef, in the Great Barrier Reef
SummaryOfEvents:
The Panamanian flag refrigerated cargo ship Peacock, on a ballast passage from Singapore to New Plymouth, New Zealand, embarked a licensed pilot off Goods Island at 16:30 hours AEST on 17 July 1996 for the passage through the Torres Strait and the Inner Two Way Route of the Great Barrier Reef. 
At about 01:55 hours on 18 July 1996, the ship grounded on Piper Reef at full speed, in a position 100 metres eastward of the light beacon. Initial attempts to refloat the her by going astern on the engine were unsuccessful. 
Peacock remained stranded on Piper Reef until the late afternoon of 26 July 1996, when salvors successfully refloated the ship after having transferred some of the fuel oil bunkers to a barge. 
The shipâs hull was not breached and no pollution occurred. However, machinery tests showed that only one steering motor was fully functional, therefore Peacock was towed to Cairns for necessary repairs.

SOLASStatus: BRONZE WING: Unknown/unspecified, RIVER EMBLEY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
The Australian bulk carrier River Embley sailed from Gladstone on the afternoon of 8 July 1996 on its regular voyage to Weipa to load bauxite. By 01:00 hours on 10 July, River Embley was approaching Little Fitzroy Light at a speed of 16 knots. At about 01:15 hours, three ships were seen north west of Little Fitzroy Light, on River Embleyâs port bow, the closest and the only one liable to pass close to River Embley was at a distance of 8 miles. At about 01:19 hours, River Embley altered course from 344 to 320 on the track to Low Isles. 
At about 23:30 hours on the night of 9 July 1996, the fishing ship âBronze Wingâ sailed from Cairns for Gibson Reef, about 46 miles south-south- east of Cairns, to collect aquarium fish. The ship cleared Cairns fairway channel and set course for Cape Grafton. From a position about a mile off Cape Grafton and making good a speed of between 6 knots and 7 knots, the ship was to follow a predetermined track to a position between 1 mile and 1.6 miles off Little Fitzroy Lighthouse. At about 01:19 hours, the Deckhand on watch on board Bronze Wing saw a large ship on the starboard bow at 6 miles on the radar and confirmed the shipâs location by a visual sighting. 
The two ships collided at about 01:34 hours, with the starboard bow of the fishing ship coming into contact with the starboard side of River Embleyâs hull, forward of mid length. Bronze Wing suffered significant damage, but River Embleyâs paint work was only superficially scratched. Nobody suffered any significant injury and no pollution resulted. 
After the collision the two ships contacted each other by VHF Radio. When it was determined that Bronze Wing did not require assistance and would return to Cairns under her own power, River Embley resumed course for Weipa.

Location: Near the entrance of the Juan the Fuca Strait
SummaryOfEvents:
On 6th July 1996 the GOLDEN PRINCESS was bound from San Francisco to Vancouver with 839 passengers and 412 crew on board. While approaching the entrance to the Juan de Fuca Strait a fire developed in No. 4 engine. 

The fire was fought initially by a fire-fighting party using foam. When forced to retire due to the building up of heat and smoke, the engine room was evacuated, sealed off and flooded with carbon dioxide. The fire was extinguished 54 minutes after initial detection.

The build up of heat caused the generators, including the emergency generator, to shut down automatically, and the ship was without main electrical power for a short time. Emergency lighting was powered by batteries when the generators stopped. 

The Master alerted the United States Coastguard, who, in association with Transport Canada arranged for assistance to be provided. The ship was taken under tow and there were no injuries, loss of life or pollution arising from the incident. 

The United States Coastguard and Transport Canada participated in the investigation conducted by the Bahamas Maritime Authority.

SOLASStatus: KOKOPO CHIEF: Unknown/unspecified, MAN WAI 0063: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On the morning of 24 June 1996 ship M.V. Kokopo Chief collided with a fishing ship Man Wai 0063. The collision occurred in position 24Â° 12.9 N   118Â° 43.4 E. The result of the collision was that the Man Wai 0063 was abandoned upon impact and soon after sank, resulting in the loss of one crew onboard

On 12 June 1996, the STS Leeuwin was cruising in the Timor Sea. On board, in addition to the permanent and volunteer crew, were 31 trainees, mainly young unemployed persons, drawn from all over the Northern Territory and sponsored by the Commonwealth Employment Service. 
Shortly after 08:30 hours, a team of three trainees, led by their Watch Leader, climbed aloft on the mainmast, to release the gaskets securing the main gaff topsail, so the sail could be set. The second of the three trainees, a woman in her late twenties, fell as she negotiated the futtock shrouds. Although she had clipped on her safety line, the free end of her safety belt slipped through the buckle and she fell 18 metres to the deck. 
Fortunately, the fall was partially broken by the nock sail sheet. Even so, the trainee suffered severe multiple fractures to her knees and to her thighs, also a collapsed lung. A helicopter medivac was arranged to transfer her to the Royal Darwin Hospital, where she remained in intensive care for 16 days.

On 10 June 1996 at approximately 08:55 hours (local time used throughout report), an explosion and fire took place on board the Product Tanker Cury, Official Number 5050. The explosion occurred aboard the Cury in the Arabian Sea during a voyage from Mina Abdullah, Kuwait to Mumbai (formerly Bombay), India when hot work was being conducted to repair wasted plating in way of the No. 4 foam monitor platform. As a result of the explosion and fire, one crewmember was killed and two others were injured with first and third degree burns over various parts of theirs bodies. The ship also received substantial damage to the No.7 center cargo thank, port and starboard slop tanks and the pumproom
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
On 13 May 1996, the Liberian flag bulk carrier Docebay was on ballast passage from Japan to Dalrymple bay in Queensland. At 04:00 hours, the ship was at the position 13Â°47.7 S, 153Â°56.8 E, approximately 500 nautical miles north-east of Townsville. 
At about 04:05 hours the first engineer heard the sound of fireand felt heat through their common bulkhead. After 1 hour 45 minutes the fire was extinguished. It had gutted the Second Engineer cabin and caused extensive smoke damage to other areas on the same deck. Nobody was injured during the incident.
The ship anchored at Hay Point on 14 May before lading its cargo of 130,000 tonnes of coal for Praia Mole in Brazil

On 18 April 1996, the SOUTHERN VENTURE left Pusan, Korea en route to New Castle, Austaralia. The second Mate plotted the course and the Master of the vessel approved the plot for the voyage. On 20 April 1996, the vessel set for open ocean and the second Mate transferred the course data on a larger scale charts and kept track of course with hourly positions taken with the GPS. At approximately 12.01 on 20 April 1996, the vessel went aground at Oki-No-Tori-Shima, a charted reef at position 20 25.7N/136 05.1E.

At 1612 on 27 March 1996, the SANKO QUEST was northbound on the Mississippi river heading to Baton rouge, Louisiana when the vessel took a violent swing to port. The Master attempted to get the vessel under control but the vessel was slow to respond. As the vessel came under control the Master attempted to steer the vessel between two ships in the Belle Chasse anchorage. The Master realized that he was too close to the West bank of the river to clear the starboard sides of the anchored vessels so he attempted to pass on the port. At 1614, the SANKO QUEST fouled the starboard anchor chain of the MOSLAVINA and collided with the vessel's starboard side. There were no injuries and no pollution as a result of this casualty. The SANKO QUEST hold its port bow and the MOSLAVINA sustained a crack in ists starboard side.

The vessel was enroute from Gabes to Limerick (IRE) with a full of cargo of fertilizer. 
On 16/03/96 at 09:00 the vessel collided with the M/V "VRISSI" (Cyprus flag) just east of the VTSZ "Off Cape Bon" at good overall weather conditions, wind Bft. 5, good visibility.
Prime cause for this collision was the OOW of the "VRISSI" who failed to keep to lookout and to manoeuvre with utmost care while he was leaving the VTSZ with easterly courses. He therefore failed to comply with reg. 15 of COLREG. 
The Master of M/V "BREITENBURG" failed also to comply with reg. 17 b)  of COLREG which request him to manoeuvre with utmost care while he was approaching the VTSZ with westerly courses. 
Both vessels were able to transit for emergency repairs in Malta.
No loss of life or injuries. The manning of M/V "BREITENBURG" was in accordance with the minimum safe manning requirements of his administration.

On the morning of 5 March 1996, the Indonesian 33,747 tonnes deadweight geared bulk carrier Bogasari Dua and the Panamanian 38,313 tonnes deadweight geared bulk carrier Midas were both lying at anchor in Geraldton Roads, Western Australia. Midas was anchored about 1 miles to the north of Bogasari Dua. 
At about 04:00 hours, Bogasari Dua, lying to a single starboard anchor with eight shackles in 30 m of water, began to drag anchor in gale force southerly winds and was driven towards Midas. Those on the bridge of Bogasari Dua did not realise that the ship was dragging anchor until after 04:30 hours, when they were alerted by the whistle signals of Midas. Bogasari Dua came into contact with Midas at about 04:45 hours, before either the anchor could be weighed, or the engine made ready. As soon as the two ships moved apart, at about 04:50 hours, the Master of Bogasari Dua manoeuvred his ship clear. 
Bogasari Dua received damage to port side shell plating in way of no.5 hold, to the main deck bulwark on the port side, to the port side accommodation ladder hoist, to the port side lifeboat davit base and to the port lifeboat, which was split into three sections. Midas received indentation damage to the bulbous bow, also to shipside plating in way of nos. one and two starboard topside tanks and damage to various lengths of shipside railing. 
No one was injured in the incident and no pollution occurred.

Location: Off Brazil at Sao Francisco do Sul

SummaryOfEvents: On 16 February 1996, the STRESA was proceeding eastbound in the Singapore Straits when a tug and tow on its starboard bow started to move into deeper water causing an overtaking situation. The STRESA passed on the port side of the tug and tow at 2117 and was in the westbound channel. At 2119 the STRESA altered course and moved back into the eastbound lane. At approximately 2120, the LANGKAPURI STAR AQUARIUS had just entered the wesbound lane and from all indications was on a course to pass to the stern of the STRESA. The LANGKAPURI STAR AQUARIUS altered her course to port and at 2123 the collision was imminent and the STRESA altered her course hard to starboard. At 2125, the LANKAPURI STAR AQUARIUS hit the port bow of the STESA. As a result of the collision approximately 30 tons of light Arab crude oil was spilled. There were two crew and two passengers treated for minor injuries on the LANGKAPURI STAR AQUARIUS. There were no injury on the STRESA.

In the earlier morning of 31 January 1996, Casey Chouest, an offshore research ship engaged in seismic survey operations, was in the prospect area known as Snark 3D, close to Thevenard Island in Western Australia. At about 07:00 hours, the fire alarm panel in the wheel house indicated a fire in the seismic compressor room space and smoke could be seen coming from the vents.
The fire fighting tug, Total Endeavour, was sent to the scene in response to a request from the master and, using its fire monitors, applied boundary cooling to the hull while the crew continued boundary cooling on board.
The fire was extinguished at about 10:45 hours.

Location: Islet of Ramsholmen, County of Stockholm
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship was en route from Vasteras (Sweden) to Gdynia (Poland). It was ballasted. The Pilot came on board at 22:10 hours. At that time there was fog and the visibility was approximately one cable. There was drift-ice in the area. The ship was travelling at approximately 11 knots with radar working on range 1.5 NM. The fog thickened successively after 23:05 hours. 

When the ship approached the Galklubb light, where a starboard turn of approximately 15 degrees was planned, and the radar range was changed to 0.75 NM. At that point the drift-ice around Galklubb caused the radar screen to become cluttered. There was no visual with the light or the red buoy north of it. At approximately the same time that the turn was executed the green buoy outside Ramsholmen's northern point was sighted close on starboard side. It was apparent then, that the ship had passed on the wrong side of the buoy and rudder hard to starboard was instantly executed. However, the ship ran onto and over the north western shallows of the islet of Ramsholmen. As a result the alarm sounded in the engine room and the engine crew stopped the main engine. On the bridge rudder hard to port was executed, but the ship continued across the fairway. The ship was crash anchored, but ran aground bow first at the SankhÃ¤llans light, which was struck and sunk.

On Sunday 21 January 1996, the Singapore flag, 1941 tonnes deadweight livestock carrier Carabao 1, while sailing under pilotage from the privately owned Labroy wharf, Hudston Creek, Darwin, struck old Man Rock, in the East Arm of the harbour. No compartments were breached and no pollution occurred.
